title: What are examples of formal and informal sentences? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thank you Harris Umar for your A2A. I may need more information to better answer your question. Sometimes beginning writers call writing “formal” when they might mean Standard American English. There is a whole spectrum of informal to formal writing. Let's look at some examples about wedding invitations. Most Informal. Joshua meets up with his long-time friend John at the coffeeshop. Just last night Joshua and Rose finalized their wedding plans. So Joshua tells John: Hey, Rose and I have decided that we are getting married at our church on Saturday, October 25 at 530pm. Yeah, yeah, write in your calendar. We've known you forever, so it is important to us you are there. . . .Then we will have a jazz wedding reception and dinner at the church hall next door. We got Just the Standards playing and singing. Score! Less Informal. Rose sends emails to her co-workers. Good morning. Joshua and I have set a date for the wedding. The ceremony will be at the Methodist church on Alameda on Saturday, October 25th at 530pm. Afterwards we will have Just the Standards to play and sing at out reception and dinner. Let us know. Informal. Rose's mother sends out e-invitations. You are cordially invited to a wedding. Stella Bigheart announces the wedding of her daughter Rosemary Bigheart to Richard Lionheart, son of the deceased Mr and Mrs Ronald Lionheart. The ceremony will take place on Saturday, October 25, 2017 at 530pm at St John’s Methodist Church at 1234 Alameda Ave in Lovely City, Texas. RSVP. Formal. The printed and mailed invitation stating all the information in Stella’s e-invitations. Hope this helps.

some examples — The main difference between formal and informal sentences has to do with the choice of vocabulary. Informal language uses colloquial expressions and slang more often. In ordinary conversation, most people speak informally. Formal language is reserved for business writing, or elevated occasions when someone is expected to speak in a more dignified way to show respect and decorum. Formal: That child is distressed. Informal: That kid is freaking out. Formal: He’s an attractive man. Informal: He’s a hottie. Formal: I’m short on funds. Informal: I’m broke. Formal: That’s very unfortunate. Informal: That sucks. Formal: She’s a difficult person. Informal: She’s a bitch. Formal: I’m pleased to meet you. Informal: Hi, how’re you doing? Formal: Good-bye. Informal: See ya.
